title: A Bit of Relief: Introducing ‘Sugar Calling’
description: In this excerpt from a new Times podcast, Cheryl Strayed calls up author George Saunders, her old friend and mentor.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen A. Miller
title: The Rise of Virtual Races
description: Runners may be running alone, but they can still feel as if they’re part of a larger group.
content: Welcome to the Running newsletter! Every Saturday morning, we email runners with news, advice and some motivation to help you get up and running. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Keep Kids Safe Online
description: A hasty primer. And, more new Parenting stories.
content: I barely knew that Facebook’s Messenger Kids app existed before the pandemic. We are pretty open to devices in my household, but if you had asked me about it, I would have said that my 7-year-old could wait a few more years to enter the social media ThunderDome. But that was before she had been separated from all her friends for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: Rangers Prospect K’Andre Miller Faces Racial Abuse in a Team Video Chat
description: After the chat, the Rangers and the N.H.L. condemned the repeated use of a slur by a hacker.
content: K’Andre Miller, a top prospect for the Rangers, was repeatedly subjected to a racial slur when a team-sponsored online video chat was hacked on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Antonio de Luca
title: ‘Dear Customers’: These Are the Emotional Store Signs of a Closed New York
description: From newly darkened storefronts, businesses offered a few last words of empathy, resolve and humor.
content: All along the empty streets of Manhattan, the messages reach out from the newly darkened storefronts. The notes express empathy, resolve, concern, even humor — a reflection of New York’s spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlyn Greenidge
title: The Hollowness of ‘This, Too, Shall Pass’
description: Black women have been telling one another that things will get better for generations. Then came the coronavirus.
content: “I’m not sure if I should go to dance class,” my niece said. This was on March 14, when it still seemed possible that life could return to normal. She is in middle school and has gone to the same Saturday dance class for nearly a decade. She spoke casually, but we knew what she meant. She wasn’t sure, for the first time, whether it was safe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 31 Slow Cooker Recipes to Cook All Day
description: Slow cooker white bean Parmesan soup, BBQ pulled pork, and many more recipes.
content: Here are more than two dozen recipes to cook in the slow cooker while you’re doing other things — or nothing at all! You could make white bean Parmesan soup (above), chicken tortellini tomato soup, BBQ pulled pork, or any of the recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A $200 Million Delay Means Lean Times for Many Olympic Athletes
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 4, 2020.
content: “We have a rainy-day fund, but it’s raining awfully hard, awfully fast.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 4, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 4, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about President Trump’s support for a possible oil deal between Saudi Arabia and Russia misstated the amount of the recent stimulus package. It was $2.2 trillion, not $2.2 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Memories of the 1918 Pandemic From Those Who Survived
description: Oral histories tell the stories of “garages full of caskets” during an influenza strain that killed at least a half-million Americans.
content: Nearly everyone who survived the 1918 flu pandemic, which claimed at least half a million American lives, has since died. But their memories, preserved in oral history interviews, shed light on its indelible impact. Bustling major cities and rural towns were brought to their knees, as transportation, law enforcement, commerce and civic life were wiped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Andy Kravis makes his cryptic debut in comedic collaboration with Andrew J. Ries.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Most of the Puns and Anagrams puzzles we get now are from Andrew J. Ries, who does a bang-up job with them, but I was happy to see the addition of Andy Kravis to the mix. He and another constructor, Natan Last, run a class at the Jewish Association Serving the Aging that teaches crossword construction and produces occasional daily crossword grids for the Times that are always hilarious and quirky. Today’s puzzle has some class-clown elements that make me think of those puzzles, and Mr. Kravis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: There Is No Way Out but Through
description: We are connected to one another and to generations past and future.
content: My sister, who lives in London, has been passing lockdown time going through old slides of my father’s, discovered last year. Every now and then she sends me a grainy or mildewed photograph, a message in a bottle from across the ocean. The pandemic has prompted a universal time of reflection. The past, more present, is the new field of exploration, absent movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Haeberle and Patricia Cohen
title: Photos: In Rural Towns and on Remote Farms, the Virus Creeps In
description: In places where social distancing was already a way of life, the relentless pandemic has begun to reshape the economy.
content: John Maley’s 28,000-acre ranch sits on the eastern edge of Steens Mountain Wilderness, a sprawling high desert in a remote corner of southeastern Oregon that’s thick in season with sagebrush, juniper and mountain mahogany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh, Emma Cott, Natalie Reneau and Suhasini Raj
title: Modi Denies India Is Targeting Muslims. We Found a Different Reality.
description: How can someone who’s lived for years as a citizen of India, suddenly be declared illegal? Whistle-blowers told us how Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is making Muslims stateless.
content: How can someone who’s lived for years as a citizen of India, suddenly be declared illegal? Whistle-blowers told us how Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party is making Muslims stateless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanif Abdurraqib
title: Keeping Bill Withers Alive
description: The three-time Grammy Award winning artist has died. In this moment of isolation, I wanted to see him alive again. And I did.
content: Even before a pandemic caused this endless ache for the community of the outside world; before the puddles on my city block no longer reflected the buzzy lights from open shops at night; and before I spoke to everyone I loved through a parade of various screens (“Zooms,” “Hangouts,” “FaceTimes”), I had gotten in the habit of watching old concert videos in the mornings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Waltemath
title: We Will Need New Ways to Grieve
description: After presiding over our church’s memorial service for my friend, I realized I needed my own ritual to mark the loss.
content: DECATUR, Ga. — Last year, on Easter Monday, my friend Genia — a 47-year-old woman in my congregation, a mother of two kids the same ages as my own — died of breast cancer. Ten years ago, she was the first person I met after my husband and I arrived here from New York City to co-pastor the church her extended family had helped start generations before.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Outdated Law Is Preventing Me From Saving Lives
description: Florida hospitals will need all hands on deck.
content: Florida hospitals will need all hands on deck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: In Congress, Doctors Are Pressing for a More Aggressive Coronavirus Response
description: There are about two dozen medical professionals in Congress, including 17 doctors, plus a former health secretary. Some are trying to shape the coronavirus response.
content: WASHINGTON — There were just 160 documented cases of the coronavirus in the United States when Representative Raul Ruiz, Democrat of California, told Vice President Mike Pence in a closed-door meeting that President Trump needed to “think about declaring a national emergency.” It took nine more days for Mr. Trump to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: The Growing Culture of Secrecy at Guantánamo Bay
description: The war court where the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks are on trial operates under classification rules that are inconsistent, complex and sometimes absurd.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson and Abby Goodnough
title: Just When They’re Needed Most, Clinics for the Poor Face Drastic Cutbacks
description: Clinics that treat the poor and uninsured are facing hard times just when they are most needed. The coronavirus pandemic has depleted their revenues.
content: SEATTLE — Providers of health care in the nation’s poorest neighborhoods are used to toiling below the radar, treating chronic diseases and other ravages of poverty in places many Americans never see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson and Abby Goodnough
title: Just When They’re Needed Most, Clinics for the Poor Face Drastic Cutbacks
description: Clinics that treat the poor and uninsured are facing hard times just when they are most needed. The coronavirus pandemic has depleted their revenues.
content: SEATTLE — Providers of health care in the nation’s poorest neighborhoods are used to toiling below the radar, treating chronic diseases and other ravages of poverty in places many Americans never see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: How Bill Withers Defined Soulful Selflessness
description: He treated his utterly distinctive voice as a vehicle, not a centerpiece, and wrote songs about everyday lives with remarkable compassion.
content: The music of Bill Withers radiated a quality that’s rare in pop songs and, really, anywhere else: selflessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Thirsty on the Set: Fans Spot Water Bottle Gaffes in ‘Little Women’
description: Close watchers of the movie have pointed out what it has in common with “Game of Thrones.”
content: When Greta Gerwig’s adaptation of Louisa May Alcott’s “Little Women” was released last year, it drew widespread acclaim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 11 Days After Fuming About a Coughing Passenger, a Bus Driver Died From the Coronavirus
description: Jason Hargrove, a bus driver in Detroit, posted a widely viewed Facebook video that underscored the dangers blue-collar workers face as they find themselves on the front lines of the pandemic.
content: Jason Hargrove was furious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and David McCabe
title: Administration Turns to Private Firms to Help Process Small Business Aid
description: The Small Business Administration is hiring companies, some with political connections, to ensure it can handle the flood of applications for help in the wake of the economy’s stall.
content: WASHINGTON — The Small Business Administration doled out tens of millions of dollars in contracts in recent days — including $50 million for a contract linked to the firm of a friend and donor to President Trump — to help it deal with the deluge of loan applications from businesses ravaged by the coronavirus-triggered economic collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: How Black Girls Get Pushed Out of School
description: The debate about the school-to-prison pipeline has largely been centered on boys. Meet the author and academic who has worked to change that.
content: The tiny voice sent shock waves across the nation. “What are those for?” the 6-year-old girl asked the police officer who pulled out zip ties that he would soon fasten around her wrists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: Suellen Rocca, Founding Member of the Hairy Who, Dies at 76
description: Ms. Rocca and five other Chicago artists came together in the 1960s to form a group whose rambunctious style tacked hard against prevailing art orthodoxies.
content: Suellen Rocca, a founding member of the short-lived but influential 1960s Chicago art group the Hairy Who and a fiercely original artist whose hieroglyphic, phantasmagoric work poked a finger in the eye of late-20th-century modernist purities, died on March 26 at a hospice in Naperville, Ill., a suburb of Chicago. She was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: He Needs Jobless Benefits. He Was Told to Find a Fax Machine.
description: Thousands of newly unemployed New Yorkers desperate to stay afloat are being frustrated by the state’s 1970s-era technology.
content: Mohammed Saiful Islam got a taste of how antiquated the technology that runs New York State’s unemployment-insurance system is when he had to go to a Staples store in the middle of a pandemic to fax his pay stubs to Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Coronavirus in America: A Highlight Reel
description: More than half of humankind is putting life on hold so that others may live. We asked readers to share the moments that are inspiring them through a time of crisis.
content: The coronavirus pandemic should give hope to all those who have despaired at humankind’s unwillingness to peacefully coexist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How Many Coronavirus Cases Are in Each California County?
description: Saturday: A special edition of California Today.
content: (Here’s the sign-up, if you don’t already get California Today delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Maccarone
title: Op-Art: Recovery in Isolation
description: “I expected sobriety to be easier when I was forced to stay home…”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: He Needs Jobless Benefits. He Was Told to Find a Fax Machine.
description: Thousands of newly unemployed New Yorkers desperate to stay afloat are being frustrated by the state’s 1970s-era technology.
content: Mohammed Saiful Islam got a taste of how antiquated the technology that runs New York State’s unemployment-insurance system is when he had to go to a Staples store in the middle of a pandemic to fax his pay stubs to Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How Many Coronavirus Cases Are in Each California County?
description: Saturday: A special edition of California Today.
content: (Here’s the sign-up, if you don’t already get California Today delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: He Went to Jared
description: Heaven help us, we’re at the mercy of the Slim Suit crowd.
content: A few years ago, when some photos by Times photographers adorning our office walls were swapped out for others, I found one headed for the dumpster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimberly Berggren
title: An Outdated Law in Florida Is Preventing Me From Saving Lives
description: We need to get physician assistants off the sidelines and into the emergency rooms.
content: Across the country, hospitals are overflowing with coronavirus patients, and health care workers are scrambling to keep up. Physician assistants are trained as generalists — but in several states, including Florida, the help they are able to provide is limited not by their ability but by strict supervision agreements with a specific physician. This administrative red tape creates barriers for hospitals in need of workers during an all-hands-on-deck crisis. In the above video, Kimberly Berggren, a physician assistant in Florida, implores Gov. Ron DeSantis to join states like New York and Michigan and remove restrictions in her state so hospitals can get the help they need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Joana Avillez
title: 24 Hours in a Pandemic Nation
description: A virtual recovery meeting. A police officer donned in a face mask. A pastor without a congregation. A funeral director trying to bury the dead. This is a new America.
content: The merciless threat slipped into America, emptying its streets, shuttering its stores, wrecking its economy and forcing its people to retreat indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rose and Sumit Agarwal
title: The Military Should Airlift New York City’s Coronavirus Patients
description: Its hospitals are overcrowded and other cities have capacity.
content: Shortly after the start of the Cold War, the Soviets blockaded the roads, railways and canals leading to West Berlin in 1948. Overnight, some two million people were cut off from food and fuel. The Western allies panicked, but under the leadership of President Harry Truman, the crisis was solved with the Berlin Airlift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Meeting Is Delayed as Saudi and Russian Tensions Flare
description: The meeting, planned for Monday, had buoyed hopes for a quick deal to end the turmoil in oil markets.
content: A meeting planned for Monday between officials of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other oil producers, which had buoyed hopes for a deal to end the turmoil in energy markets, has been put off, according to two OPEC delegates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly, Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Private Equity Firm Pushes for Broader Access to Fed Lending Program
description: Apollo has led a push to expand a program intended to keep loans flowing to small businesses and households by allowing for more kinds of assets to be offered as collateral.
content: As government officials fight to prevent an economic depression by setting up emergency lending programs to keep credit flowing to taxpayers and small businesses, a prominent private equity firm is pushing to ensure that a broader spectrum of investments are included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: In Georgia, Shelter-in-Place Order Closes Businesses and Reopens Beaches
description: The order supersedes actions taken by some coastal communities, and it reflects the tensions between state and local officials across the country in responding to the coronavirus.
content: ATLANTA — Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia signed a shelter-in-place order on Thursday, shutting down restaurant dining rooms, barbershops, bars and gyms across the state. He called it an effort to buy critical time as Georgia braced for a surge in cases of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: He Went to Jared
description: Heaven help us, we’re at the mercy of the Slim Suit crowd.
content: A few years ago, when some photos by Times photographers adorning our office walls were swapped out for others, I found one headed for the dumpster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry and Caitlin Dickerson
title: The Killer Flu of 1918: A Philadelphia Story
description: The brutal toll taken by the flu that claimed 20,000 lives in the city has not been forgotten as Philadelphia braces for the worst of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: PHILADELPHIA — At Sunday family dinners, the grandchildren would beg to hear that story again, the one about her twins in the baby carriage, and one of them was dead, and what did she do. This was when Sarah Jane Anderson would add to the collective memory of a Philadelphia nightmare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Meeting Is Delayed as Saudi and Russian Tensions Flare
description: The meeting, planned for Monday, had buoyed hopes for a quick deal to end the turmoil in oil markets.
content: A meeting planned for Monday between officials of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Russia and other oil producers, which had buoyed hopes for a deal to end the turmoil in energy markets, has been put off, according to two OPEC delegates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: 2 Killed in Knife Attack in French Town Under Lockdown
description: A Sudanese man was detained as a suspect in the attack on bystanders in Romans-sur-Isère in what officials described as potentially a terrorist attack.
content: PARIS — In what was described as a potential terrorist attack, a knife-wielding man killed two people and wounded five others on Saturday morning in a town in southern France with only a few shops open under a national lockdown to stem the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Barr Expands Early Release of Inmates at Prisons Seeing More Coronavirus Cases
description: The attorney general directed the Bureau of Prisons to prioritize the early release of some prisoners from federal correctional institutions in Louisiana, Connecticut and Ohio.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr ordered the Bureau of Prisons on Friday to expand the group of federal inmates eligible for early release and to prioritize those at three facilities where known coronavirus cases have grown precipitously, as the virus threatens to overwhelm prison medical facilities and nearby hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Operate On With a Beam
description: Don’t worry, this Yacob Yonas puzzle won’t hurt a bit.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — We’ve seen Yacob Yonas’s work before, but only in collaboration. Today’s grid is fairly quick and sunny for a Saturday, but there are several good new terms, and I could see the configuration making problems for solvers if anyone got stumped in a corner. Maybe I just got lucky? There’s certainly a lot to like in the cluing, some wry humor and some interesting bits and pieces. That LAB sneaked up on me!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Matthew Futterman
title: The $200 Million the Olympics Postponement Took From Team U.S.A.
description: The Summer Olympics in Tokyo have been postponed a year. That means nearly $200 million in funding, which American athletes depend on for living and training expenses, likely won’t arrive until next August.
content: Wallace Spearmon, a two-time Olympian in track and field, got what he wanted when the International Olympic Committee finally bowed to pressure from athletes and national Olympic organizations and postponed the 2020 Tokyo Games for a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: How a Chinese-American Novelist Wrote Herself Into the Wild West
description: C Pam Zhang’s debut, “How Much of These Hills Is Gold,” is one of several new or forthcoming books by Asian-American writers set in a period that historically hasn’t recognized them.
content: The day in 2015 that C Pam Zhang was laid off from her first job out of college, she celebrated with friends at the park, then promptly made plans to move to Bangkok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: A Quarantined Uber Driver’s Quest for Paid Sick Leave
description: Zachary Frenette spent about two weeks fighting to get help under a new Uber policy. It worked, but only after he got the news media involved.
content: Zachary Frenette likes working as an Uber driver in Phoenix. He is a top-rated driver who often chats with his customers on their trips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink, Victor J. Blue and Ben Laffin
title: What It’s Like to Be a Critical Care Doctor Battling Covid-19 in New York
description: The Brooklyn Hospital Center is on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The Brooklyn Hospital Center is on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: He Kissed His Mother Goodbye. Then He Learned She Had Coronavirus.
description: A fence builder said he spent five hours with his dying mother at a Texas nursing home before learning she had tested positive for the virus.
content: Samuel Roy Quinn spent five hours with his mother on Friday, finally allowed to say goodbye as her condition deteriorated in a nursing home south of Houston. He held her hand and hugged her. He removed his face mask several times to kiss her on the forehead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Brace Yourself for Waves of Coronavirus Infections
description: Here’s what we should be expecting in the war on Covid-19.
content: In the world war against the coronavirus, there’s both very good news and very bad news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Dreger
title: What You Should Know Before You Need a Ventilator
description: It breaks my heart that patients who will get sick enough to need them won’t know what desperate situations they face.
content: Day by day, as the number of Covid-19 deaths soar, we see more clearly that many of us will not survive this storm.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Trump Warns of ‘a Lot of Death’ While Also Revisiting Easter Sunday Services
description: President Trump warns of what could be “the toughest week,” while also saying he would like to consider relaxing social distancing rules for Easter services.
content: This briefing has ended. Read our global live coverage on the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: When the Face of America Falls Ill: A Virus’s Toll on Diplomats
description: State Department employees are vulnerable and stressed by the coronavirus as it sweeps around the world, prompting thousands of American citizens to return to the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The symptoms were more annoying than alarming: A dry cough, achiness and then sniffles developed a few days after Andrew Young, the American ambassador to Burkina Faso, met with government officials and aid organizations to discuss how to protect the West African nation from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Bujalski
title: On the Streets of Los Angeles
description: The coronavirus pandemic has highlighted how vulnerable the homeless population is.
content: The coronavirus has infected over a million people around the world. As the pandemic sweeps across the country, tens of thousands of people are living on the streets of California. Last month, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California warned that as many as 60,000 homeless people could be infected with Covid-19, overwhelming the state’s health care systems. In Los Angeles County, where roughly 60,000 people are homeless, there are at least nine confirmed cases of coronavirus among unsheltered people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Telemedicine Arrives in the U.K.: ‘10 Years of Change in One Week’
description: With the coronavirus pandemic turning doctors’ offices into no-go zones, family physicians are now doing much of their consultations online or by telephone.
content: LONDON — A housebound 92-year-old man had red, throbbing legs. A younger patient was complaining of a lump in his armpit. And the self-isolating residents of a nursing home needed checkups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Leading by Example, Some Politicians Urge Residents to Wear Face Masks
description: Across the country, state and local politicians have begun donning protective gear, in contrast to President Trump, who said he wouldn’t follow the C.D.C. guidance.
content: Now that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has encouraged Americans to wear masks when they venture outside, more state and local politicians have begun donning the protective gear themselves, standing in contrast to President Trump, who says the masks aren’t his style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Can You Lead in a Pandemic Without Picking Sides? Greg Abbott Is Trying
description: The Texas governor hasn’t defied President Trump, like some of his fellow Republican governors have. He also hasn’t ignored public health recommendations. He’s aiming for crisis management that doesn’t rock the boat.
content: On Thursday, in a public service announcement filmed in his wood-paneled office, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas gestured toward his most recent executive order propped up in front of him, one that Democrats, health care professionals, and a growing number of Republicans in the state had been clamoring for. Beginning that day, he said, all Texans were required to “stay at home, except to provide essential services or do essential things, like going to the grocery store.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: He Says His Nazi Days Are Over. Do You Believe Him?
description: Jeff Schoep led America’s largest neo-Nazi group for two decades. He now says he wants to help destroy it.
content: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — It was a panel discussion on a college campus about the importance of rejecting extremism. And one of the supposed experts on tolerance participating was Jeff Schoep, a man who once called the deadly white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., “a glorious day for white solidarity in America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: A German Exception? Why the Country’s Coronavirus Death Rate Is Low
description: The pandemic has hit Germany hard, with more than 92,000 people infected. But the percentage of fatal cases has been remarkably low compared to those in many neighboring countries.
content: They call them corona taxis: Medics outfitted in protective gear, driving around the empty streets of Heidelberg to check on patients who are at home, five or six days into being sick with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: College Made Them Feel Equal. The Virus Exposed How Unequal Their Lives Are.
description: When they were all in the same dorms and eating the same dining hall food, the disparities in students’ backgrounds weren’t as clear as they are over video chat.
content: The political science class was called “Forced Migration and Refugees.” Students read accounts of migrants fleeing broken economies and seeking better futures, of life plans drastically altered and the political forces that made it all seem necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Proceeds With Post-Impeachment Purge Amid Pandemic
description: The president’s decision to fire the intelligence community’s inspector general under cover of darkness indicated that his hunt for those he considers disloyal continues.
content: WASHINGTON — Remember the impeachment? President Trump does. Even in the middle of a deadly pandemic, he made clear on Saturday that he remained fixated on purging the government of those he believes betrayed him during the inquiry that led to his Senate trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Coronavirus Models Offer the Big Picture, Not the Details of What May Come
description: Ontario and British Columbia have both released their projections about what the pandemic will bring. But, like a weather forecast, they are ever-shifting predictions.
content: Ontario followed British Columbia on Friday by releasing its projections for what may lie ahead in those provinces with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and James Glanz
title: Tensions Persist Between Trump and Medical Advisers Over the Coronavirus
description: The president’s public refusal to wear a mask was the latest way he has cast doubt on their recommendations.
content: WASHINGTON — Rarely has the schism between President Trump and his own public health advisers over the coronavirus pandemic been put on display quite so starkly. Even as he announced a new federal recommendation on Friday that Americans wear masks when out in public, he immediately disavowed it: “I am choosing not to do it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: A Master of Thrills Shows His Range, and His Bite
description: In his new collection of novellas, “Broken,” Don Winslow pays playful tribute to forebears from Raymond Chandler to Steve McQueen.
content: If you’ve read only a few of Don Winslow’s books, you may not realize what a shape-shifter he is. His bravura Cartel trilogy, with its 40-year wingspan and brutally detailed knowledge of Mexican drug gangs, isn’t much like his darkly hilarious “Savages,” which itself barely shows how deeply his early books were rooted in California’s surf culture. All they share is indelible bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karina Piser
title: My Grandmother’s Lost Cookie Recipe
description: I tried to make her cachkitas — savory cookies full of butter and cumin, and topped with sesame seeds.
content: My grandmother left her recipes in fragments. There’s her little black book, scribbles of ingredients in English, French and Ladino, the language once spoken by the Jews of Spain, Portugal, Greece and Turkey. In one recipe, Savta, grandma in Hebrew, based measurements on a yogurt cup which she called un gobelet. According to my mom, they didn’t see a measuring cup until they moved from Israel to America in the early 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Láolú Senbanjo
title: A Virus Doesn’t Care Where You’re From
description: The pandemic makes clear there is no such thing as a “Chinese” or “African” virus.
content: Crisis is a cruel teacher. During times of crisis, when people let their guard down, we get to see what’s really behind the facade. Often, it’s not pretty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Klitzman
title: Doctors Need Room to Make the Wrenching Decisions They Face
description: New York is granting health care providers civil and criminal immunity during the coronavirus emergency. So should other states.
content: Doctors are trained to do everything they can to save their patients’ lives. This imperative is fundamental and deeply ingrained. But the Covid-19 pandemic is turning this goal — and the very practice of medicine — upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Double Talk
description: Jim Peredo’s Sunday puzzle has an expression for every occasion.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jim Peredo is a steady contributor with nine New York Times puzzles, but we haven’t seen a weekend grid from him since 2014. I know him only from the Grumpy Cat memorial puzzle, his most recent, but I find his style of cluing really distinctive and enjoyable. Will Shortz’s introduction refers to geocaching as one of Mr. Peredo’s inspirations; I was struck by the number of interesting historical figures that come up today, from all walks of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Láolú Senbanjo
title: A Virus Doesn’t Care Where You’re From
description: The pandemic makes clear there is no such thing as a “Chinese” or “African” virus.
content: Crisis is a cruel teacher. During times of crisis, when people let their guard down, we get to see what’s really behind the facade. Often, it’s not pretty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Klitzman
title: Doctors Need Room to Make the Wrenching Decisions They Face
description: New York is granting health care providers civil and criminal immunity during the coronavirus emergency. So should other states.
content: Doctors are trained to do everything they can to save their patients’ lives. This imperative is fundamental and deeply ingrained. But the Covid-19 pandemic is turning this goal — and the very practice of medicine — upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman and James Glanz
title: Tensions Persist Between Trump and Medical Advisers Over the Coronavirus
description: The president’s public refusal to wear a mask was the latest way he has cast doubt on their recommendations.
content: WASHINGTON — Rarely has the schism between President Trump and his own public health advisers over the coronavirus pandemic been put on display quite so starkly. Even as he announced a new federal recommendation on Friday that Americans wear masks when out in public, he immediately disavowed it: “I am choosing not to do it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Double Talk
description: Jim Peredo’s Sunday puzzle has an expression for every occasion.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jim Peredo is a steady contributor with nine New York Times puzzles, but we haven’t seen a weekend grid from him since 2014. I know him only from the Grumpy Cat memorial puzzle, his most recent, but I find his style of cluing really distinctive and enjoyable. Will Shortz’s introduction refers to geocaching as one of Mr. Peredo’s inspirations; I was struck by the number of interesting historical figures that come up today, from all walks of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Bill Withers’s 10 Overlooked Songs
description: The soulful singer with a gift for writing understated classics has died at 81. Beyond his hits (“Lean on Me,” “Ain’t No Sunshine”) is a trove of lesser-known gems.
content: Bill Withers always sounded like he was strumming the guitar from a seat at his kitchen table — or maybe, at his most luxurious, an easy chair in the living room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: All I Wanted Was to Be Interrogated
description: On a reporter’s 27-hour journey from Hong Kong to New York City, hardly anyone seemed to care about her health.
content: When I tell people I flew back to New York City from Hong Kong last weekend, many ask one of two questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Larry David, Master of His Quarantine
description: Who better than the father of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm” to guide us through the thicket of being together, alone?
content: Our lives now depend on staying home and doing nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: A Tennis Coach Was Abusing Minors. Should the Sport’s Federation Have Known?
description: The United States Tennis Association has asserted it can police itself when it comes to abuse cases. The story of one coach raises doubts.
content: RICHMOND, Calif. — At a meeting in Chicago in September 2014, the head of the United States Olympic Committee took note that  a new initiative to protect athletes from abusers had support from every sport’s governing body except one: the United States Tennis Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: ‘Code Blue’: A Brooklyn I.C.U. Fights for Each Life in a Coronavirus Surge
description: Nearly every patient was on a ventilator. Some were in their 80s, some in their 30s. Medical workers were falling fast and had to be resourceful — “the alternative,” one said, “is death.”
content: The night had been particularly tough. Patient after patient had to be intubated and put on a ventilator to breathe. At one point, three “codes” — emergency interventions when someone is on the brink of death — occurred at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Eder, Henry Fountain, Michael H. Keller, Muyi Xiao and Alexandra Stevenson
title: 430,000 People Have Traveled From China to U.S. Since Coronavirus Surfaced
description: There were 1,300 direct flights to 17 cities before President Trump’s travel restrictions. Since then, nearly 40,000 Americans and other authorized travelers have made the trip, some this past week and many with spotty screening.
content: Since Chinese officials disclosed the outbreak of a mysterious pneumonialike illness to international health officials on New Year’s Eve, at least 430,000 people have arrived in the United States on direct flights from China, including nearly 40,000 in the two months after President Trump imposed restrictions on such travel, according to an analysis of data collected in both countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: In Italy, Going Back to Work May Depend on Having the Right Antibodies
description: Weighing an idea that might once have been relegated to science fiction, Italy once again finds itself in the unfortunate vanguard of Western democracies grappling with the coronavirus.
content: ROME — There is a growing sense in Italy that the worst may have passed. The weeks of locking down the country, center of the world’s deadliest coronavirus outbreak, may be starting to pay off, as officials announced this week that the numbers of new infections had plateaued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Suhasini Raj
title: ‘Muslims Are Foreigners’: Inside India’s Campaign to Decide Who Is a Citizen
description: Tribunal members in the state of Assam say they felt pressured to declare Muslims noncitizens as the government seeks to expel illegal migrants. Some politicians have vowed to take the process nationwide.
content: JORHAT, India — For nearly two years, Mamoni Rajkumari, a lawyer, spent her days deciding who was an Indian citizen and who was not, as part of a tribunal reviewing suspected foreigners in the state of Assam. Then, she says, she was dismissed for not declaring enough Muslims to be noncitizens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Labour Party Has a New Leader: Keir Starmer
description: Mr. Starmer will have to battle for visibility at a time when the coronavirus crisis is eclipsing all other news and Prime Minister Boris Johnson is commanding the headlines.
content: LONDON — When Keir Starmer first emerged in early January as the front-runner to lead Britain’s Labour Party, the best he could hope for, it seemed, was to spend years in the political wilderness, opposing a Conservative prime minister, Boris Johnson, who won a landslide majority in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden Has Talked to Sanders About Process for Picking a Running Mate
description: On a virtual fund-raiser, Mr. Biden also mused aloud about filling positions like secretary of state, attorney general and chief of staff, but said, “I haven’t asked anybody yet.’’
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. said on Friday that he had discussed the process of selecting a running mate with his chief rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, even as both men continue to compete in the Democratic primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump to Fire Intelligence Watchdog Who Had Key Role in Ukraine Complaint
description: The president notified lawmakers late on Friday, saying he had lost confidence in the inspector general for the intelligence community.
content: President Trump is firing the intelligence community inspector general whose insistence on telling lawmakers about a whistle-blower complaint about his dealings with Ukraine triggered impeachment proceedings last fall, the president told lawmakers in a letter late Friday.
source.name: The New York Times
